body_text.text: Intrauterine infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the leading viral cause of developmental disorders of the central nervous system (CNS) in humans, 1,2 and more frequently causes disabilities than do other well-known childhood disorders, such as Down syndrome.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 3 Although human CMV (HCMV) can infect multiple organs, the most severe and permanent sequelae after congenital infection are those affecting the cerebrum, such as microcephaly, epilepsy, and mental retardation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: [4][5][6][7] These sequelae are found more frequently in infants infected during the first trimester, a critical period for cerebral corticogenesis, 8 than in those infected during the later trimesters.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 9 In cerebral corticogenesis, neural stem/progenitor cells (NSPCs) of the ventricular and subventricular zone (VZ and SVZ) generate the cerebral cortex through their "stemness"; that is, through their proliferation, migration, and differentiation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 10 Therefore, congenital HCMV infection can be a teratogenic factor for cortical malformations that result in the abovementioned sequelae.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In terms of the direct teratogenic action of CMV, previous in vitro studies have clearly demonstrated that murine and human NSPCs infected with murine CMV (MCMV) and HCMV, respectively, lose their stemness.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: [11][12][13] Although growing evidence indicates that inflammatory reactions triggered by infectious agents have serious impacts on immature developing brains and are possibly related to brain malformations and neurodevelopmental disorders, [14][15][16][17] most of the evidence is based on studies using bacterial and viral mimics, such as lipopolysaccharide and polyinocinic-polycytidylic acid.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 14,17 In other words, fetal immune reactions to neuroinvasion with a live virus and the influence of the immune reactions on cerebral corticogenesis have not yet been well investigated.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 18 Although studies on human subjects have obvious limitations, and while CMV has strict species specificity, in vivo model systems using mouse embryos and neonates infected with MCMV have nevertheless shed light on the neuropathogenesis of congenital CMV infection.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 19,20 Previously, we developed a mouse model of intraplacental MCMV infection to simulate transplacental HCMV infection and to investigate CMV neuropathogenesis.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 21 In this model, neonatal mice infected with MCMV in utero exhibited growth retardation and microcephaly in a fashion similar to that observed in association with congenital CMV infection in humans.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, there have been no precise pathological or immunological analyses of the effects of congenital CMV infection on fetal brain development.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this study, by using a fine glass micropipette, we improved the accuracy of the intraplacental inoculation with MCMV and made the inoculation process less invasive.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The model allowed us to show the transmission of MCMV from placenta to fetal brain as well as the fetal innate immune responses, including macrophage/microglial reactions, and their impact on cerebral corticogenesis.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The wild-type Smith strain of MCMV, MCMV-Smith, which had been passaged in mouse embryonic fibroblasts, was provided by Dr. Y Minamishima (Miyazaki, Japan).
body_text.section: Virus, cells, and plaque assay

body_text.text: Construction of MCMV-EGFP, MCMV expressing enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP) under the control of the MCMV e1 promoter, was described previously.
body_text.section: Virus, cells, and plaque assay

body_text.text: 22 MCMV-EGFP and MCMV-Smith showed similar viral growth, latency, and pathogenesis.
body_text.section: Virus, cells, and plaque assay

body_text.text: 23 Mouse embryonic fibroblasts were prepared from 12.5-day-old embryos (E12.5) of BALB/c mice (SLC Japan, Hamamatsu, Japan), and were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's essential medium (DMEM) containing penicillin (100 U/mL), streptomycin (50 lg/mL), and 10% fetal bovine serum.
body_text.section: Virus, cells, and plaque assay

body_text.text: Viral titers were determined by a plaque assay using mouse embryonic fibroblasts monolayers as described previously.
body_text.section: Virus, cells, and plaque assay

body_text.text: 24 Ultraviolet light (UV)-inactivated MCMV that neither replicates nor produces any detectable level of the IE1 protein was used as a mock control.
body_text.section: Virus, cells, and plaque assay

body_text.text: Inbred specific pathogen-free pregnant C57BL/6 female mice were purchased from SLC Japan.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: All mice were housed under specific pathogen-free conditions.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: Pregnant mice were randomly divided into two groups: the MCMV-and mock-infected groups.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: MCMV inoculation to the placenta was performed via a fine glass micropipette with a diameter of 40 lm (Fig. 1A), which was made from a borosilicate glass capillary (No. 30-0019, 1.0 mm O.D. 9 0.58 mm I.D., Harvard Apparatus, Holliston, MA) using a micropipette puller (Model P-97; Sutter Instrument Company, Novato, CA), as described for transient delivery of serotonin into the placenta.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: 25 In the MCMV-infected group, 1 9 10 5 plaque-forming unit (PFU) of MCMV-Smith or MCMV-EGFP in 1 lL of DMEM was injected through the uterine wall into the labyrinth region in the placenta.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: In the mock-infected group, UV-inactivated MCMV virus in 1 lL of DMEM was injected into the placenta in the same way.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: All surgical procedures were performed under anesthesia induced by an intraperitoneal injection of 0.2-0.3 mL of 6.5 mg/mL sodium pentobarbital.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: Fetuses were surgically collected at the indicated number of days postinfection (dpi), and the number of live fetuses and dead fetuses were counted, followed by the weighing of the fetuses, placentas, and brains.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: The placenta, brain, heart, and liver were stored at À80°C and used for plaque assays, realtime polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and real-time reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR).
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: For immunohistochemical analysis and in situ hybridization, the brains were fixed by perfusion with 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA), removed, immersed in 20% sucrose, and quickly frozen in liquid nitrogen.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: Coronal sections were cut with a cryostat at 12 lm, air dried, and then stored at À80°C.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: Some of the infected brains were frozen in liquid nitrogen without fixation with PFA, serially cut, then fixed in isopropyl alcohol, and stored at À80°C.
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: For the labeling of proliferating cells, a number of pregnant mice were intraperitoneally injected with bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU, 50 mg/kg; Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO).
body_text.section: Intraplacental MCMV infection

body_text.text: DNA was extracted from tissue homogenates with Trizol (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) according to the manufacturer's protocol.
body_text.section: Real-time PCR for quantification of the MCMV copy number

body_text.text: All real-time PCRs were performed using TaqMan Gene Expression Master Mix in an ABI7500 Fast System using the standard curve (absolute quantitation) assay (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
body_text.section: Real-time PCR for quantification of the MCMV copy number

body_text.text: One hundred ng of DNA was added as template DNA to a reaction mixture that contained 29 TaqMan Reaction Mixture, 900 nmol/L primers, and 250 nmol/L TaqMan MGB probe.
body_text.section: Real-time PCR for quantification of the MCMV copy number

body_text.text: The MCMV genome was quantified by amplification of the major immediate-early promoter (MIEP) gene using the primers 5 0 -GGTGGTCAGACCGAAGACT and 5 0 -GCTGAGCTGCGTTCTACGT, and the probe 5 0 -FAM-CTGGTCGCGCCTCTTA.
body_text.section: Real-time PCR for quantification of the MCMV copy number

body_text.text: 26 As a cellular gene, the b-actin gene was quantified using primers 5 0 -CGTTCCGAAAG TTGCCTTTTA, 5-0 GCCGCCGGGTTTTATAGG, and the probe 5 0 -FAM-CTCGAGTGGCCGCTG.
body_text.section: Real-time PCR for quantification of the MCMV copy number

body_text.text: The thermal cycling conditions were one cycle at 50°C for 2 min and at 95°C for 10 min followed by 50 cycles of 95°C for 15 sec and 60°C for 1 min.
body_text.section: Real-time PCR for quantification of the MCMV copy number

body_text.text: Serial dilutions of pSM3fr bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) containing the MCMV whole genome, which was kindly provided by Dr. UH Koszinowski (Munich, Germany), 27 were used as the quantification standard for MCMV.
body_text.section: Real-time PCR for quantification of the MCMV copy number

body_text.text: Mouse monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) specific for the MCMV-IE1 nuclear antigen (Ag) (1:2000, kindly provided by Dr. S Jonjic, Rijeka, Croatia) 28 and the MCMV-E1 nuclear Ag (1:5) 29 were used for detection of MCMVinfected cells.
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: For immunoperoxidase staining, after microwave treatment, fetal brain sections were reacted with anti-IE1 mAb and then with horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG polyclonal antibody (pAb) (N-Histofine simple stain mouse MAX PO; Nichirei Bioscience, Tokyo, Japan), and colored with 3,3-diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride (DAB).
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: For immunofluorescence staining, in addition to mAb for MCMV-Ag, the following primary antibodies were used: inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS, rabbit pAb, 1:100; Abcam, Cambridge, UK), BrdU (rat mAb, 1:200; Abcam), Brn2 (goat pAb, 1:100; Santa Cruz, Dallas, TX), Tbr1 (rabbit pAb, 1:100; Chemicon, Billerica, MA), Iba-1 (rabbit pAb, 1:500, Wako, Osaka, Japan), SOX2 (rabbit pAb, 1:200; MBL, Nagoya, Japan), F4/80 (rat mAb, 1:20; AbD Serotec, Oxford, UK), CD45 (rabbit pAb, 1:100; Abcam), major histocopatibility complex (MHC) class II (rat mAb, 1:100; BioLegend, San Diego, CA), CD31 (rabbit pAb, 1:50; Abcam), and NG2 (rabbit pAb, 1:200; Millipore, Billerica, MA).
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: The following secondary antibodies were also used: Alexa Fluor 488 anti-mouse IgG1 or IgG2a, Alexa Fluor 546 anti-rabbit, -rat, or -goat IgG, or Alexa Fluor 647 anti-rabbit IgG (Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: Nuclei were stained with 4 0 ,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole, dihydrochloride (DAPI) (Sigma-Aldrich).
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: For BrdU staining, sections were incubated in 2 N HCl followed by 0.1 mol/L sodium borate after microwave treatment.
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: Confocal images were captured using an Olympus FV1000 microscope with the latest Fluoview software Ver.3.1 (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan).
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: A stack of five images from 0.5-lm step slices was combined for the analysis.
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: At least three different animals in each group were used for the analysis, and sections from three fields in each brain were evaluated.
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry

body_text.text: Using the PFA-fixed sections adjacent to the sections used for immunostaining, chromogenic in situ hybridization was performed for the detection of MCMV DNA as described previously.
body_text.section: In situ hybridization for MCMV DNA detection

body_text.text: 30 The DNA probe was made from pSM3fr BAC labeled with digoxigenin (DIG)-11-dUTP using a nick translation kit (Roche, Mannheim, Germany).
body_text.section: In situ hybridization for MCMV DNA detection

body_text.text: After hybridization, the sections were subsequently incubated with HRP-conjugated anti-DIG Fab fragments (1:100; Roche) and colored with DAB, followed by hematoxylin counterstaining.
body_text.section: In situ hybridization for MCMV DNA detection

body_text.text: At 3 and 5 dpi, mock-and MCMV-EGFP-infected fetuses were perfused through the left cardiac ventricle with 5 mL of ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), containing 2 U/mL heparin.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: Each cerebrum with meninges and the choroid plexus was minced into small fragments and then incubated in the presence of 25 U/mL DNase I and 0.01% collagenase II at 37°C for 30 min.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: The cells were filtered through a nylon screen (70 lm; BD Bioscience, San Diego, CA) to remove cell aggregates, centrifuged, and then twice washed with RPMI 1640 medium.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: The cells were incubated with antibodies against CD45-APC (1:100), CD11b-PE/Cy7 (1:100), NK1.1-APC/Cy7 (1:20), Ly-6G/Ly-6C (Gr1)-PacificBlue (1:50), Cd45R/ B220-PerCP/Cy5.5 (1:100), and CD3-Alexa Flour 700 (1:100) (BioLegend) for 30 min.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: After collection, rinsing with RPMI 1640 and filtration through a nylon screen (40 lm), the cells were sorted and analyzed on a FACSAria system (BD Bioscience).
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: Isotype antibodies were used as controls.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: To sort the mononuclear cells from each cerebrum with meninges, cells were stained with a combination of CD45-APC and CD11b-PE/Cy7, and then separated into CD45 high /CD11b + (isolated cell numbers: 10,835 AE 5593 cells in the mock-infected brain at 5 dpi, n = 6; 15,000 AE 0 cells in the MCMV-infected brain at 5 dpi, n = 4), CD45 low /CD11b + (14,314 AE 6408 cells in the mock-infected brain at 5 dpi, n = 6; 15,520 AE 1804 cells in the MCMV-infected brain at 5 dpi, n = 4), CD45 high / CD11b + (1235 AE 286.0 cells in the mock-infected brain at 5 dpi, n = 6; 1541 AE 234 cells in the MCMV-infected brain at 5 dpi, n = 4), and CD45 low /CD11b + populations (cell sorting was stopped at 100,000 cells in both the mock-and MCMV-infected brains).
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: The sorted cellular populations were stored at À80°C in Trizol and used later for RNA isolation.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: Total RNA was isolated from the frozen samples, purified with an RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) and treated with RNase-free DNase I (Qiagen), according to the manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: Real-time RT-PCR for quantification of mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators

body_text.text: One hundred nanograms of cDNA synthesized using a SuperScript III First Strand Synthesis kit with random primers (Invitrogen) was used for each PCR reaction.
body_text.section: Real-time RT-PCR for quantification of mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators

body_text.text: TaqMan assay mixtures for IL-1b (Mm00434228), INF-a4 (Mm00833969), INF-b1 (Mm00 439552), IL-10 (Mm00439614), and monocyte chemotactic protein-1 (MCP-1)/chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 2 (CCL2) (Mm00441242) were obtained from Applied Biosystems.
body_text.section: Real-time RT-PCR for quantification of mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators

body_text.text: The following primer pairs and probes were synthesized commercially (Sigma-Aldrich): iNOS, 5 0 -CA GCTGGGCTGTACAAACCTT, 5 0 -CATTGGAAGTGAAGC GTTTCG, and 5 0 -FAM-CGGGCAGCCTGTGAGACCTTT GA; IL-1b, 5 0 -CAACCAACAAGTGATATTCTCCATG, 5 0 -GATCCACACTCTCCAGCTGCA, and 5 0 -FAM-CTGTGT AATGAAAGACGGCACACCCACC; TNF-a, 5 0 -CATCTTC TCAAAATTCGAGTGCAA, 5 0 -TGGGAGTAGACAAGGTA CAACCC, 5 0 -FAM-CACGTCGTAGCAAACCACCAAGTG GA; IL-6, 5 0 -GAGGATACCACTCCCAACAGACC, 5 0 -AAG TGCATCATCGTTGTTCATACA, and 5 0 -FAM-CAGAATT GCCATTGCACAACTCTTTTCTCA; INF-c, 5 0 -TCAAGTG GCATAGATGTGGAAGAA, 5 0 -TGGCTCTGCAGGATTTT CATG, and 5 0 -FAM-TCACCATCCTTTTGCCAGTTCCTC CAG; glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAP-DH), 5 0 -TCACCACCATGGAGAAGGC, 5 0 -GCTAAGCAG TTGGTGGTGCA, and 5 0 -FAM-ATGCCCCCATGTTTGT GATGGGTGT.
body_text.section: Real-time RT-PCR for quantification of mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators

body_text.text: Real-time PCR was performed using the StepOne Plus System (Applied Biosystems).
body_text.section: Real-time RT-PCR for quantification of mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators

body_text.text: The GAPDH housekeeping gene was used as a control for all experiments.
body_text.section: Real-time RT-PCR for quantification of mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators

body_text.text: The GAP-DH expression level from the mock-infected animals was taken as 1 and the gene expression levels of the target genes were expressed as relative values.
body_text.section: Real-time RT-PCR for quantification of mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators

body_text.text: Numerical results were expressed as the mean AE standard error of mean (SEM) obtained from at least three independent experiments.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Statistical analysis was performed using an unpaired two-tailed Student's t-test.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Probability values (P) <0.05 were considered to be significant.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: As described in the Materials and Methods section, all pregnant C57BL/6 mice were treated surgically and intraplacentally infected with 1 9 10 5 PFU of MCMV, mock infected, or inoculated with DMEM using a fine glass micropipette (Fig. 1A).
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: In the first set of mice, inoculation with MCMV-Smith was performed at E11.5, E12.5, and E13.5, and the fetuses were collected at 3 dpi.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: The survival rates of the fetuses in dams infected with MCMV-Smith were 25% (2/8), 35% (13/37), and 67% (10/15) at E11.5, E12.5, and E13.5, respectively.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Those in dams infected with UV-inactivated virus (mock infected) were 50% (10/20), 63% (10/16), and 89% (8/9) at E11.5, E12.5, and E13.5, respectively.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Similar results were obtained using dams that had undergone a similar surgical procedure but were inoculated with DMEM.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Therefore, it is likely that fetuses at E11.5 and E12.5 do not readily develop in utero after surgery, and fetuses at E13.5 were used for the subsequent studies.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Next, pregnant mice were infected intraplacentally at E13.5 as described above, and the fetuses were collected at 1, 3, and 5 dpi.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Although the survival rates of the fetuses gradually decreased, the infection rates (the detection limit was 1 viral DNA copy/million cells) in the brains were 30-40% ( Fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Amplification by PCR did not reveal any MCMV genomic DNA in the placentas or brains of the mock-infected fetuses.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Pregnant mice were also infected intraplacentally with MCMV-EGFP, MCMV expressing EGFP during the viral replicative cycle, as we previously demonstrated that MCMV-EGFP grows in the same way as MCMV-Smith.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: 23 Fluorescence stereomicroscopic views of the placentas and fetuses at 3 dpi demonstrated multiple infectious foci, consisting of infected cells in a "green mirror ball" arrangement, in the fetal body surface, fetal brain, and placenta ( Fig. 1C).
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: Although the body weight of the MCMV-EGFP-infected fetuses at 5 dpi was 15% less than that of mock-infected fetuses ( Fig. 1D), both mock-and MCMV-infected mice had no macroscopic morphological abnormalities and no significant differences in the weight of the placenta and brain were observed at any time points.
body_text.section: Establishment of a congenital infection model using intraplacental MCMV inoculation

body_text.text: The viral titers of MCMV-Smith in the placenta peaked at 3 dpi, while the titers in the other organs increased until 5 dpi ( Fig. 2A).
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: The viral DNA copy numbers in all organs increased in parallel (Fig. 2B).
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: Viral loads in the placenta, liver, and heart exceeded those in the brain, suggesting that MCMV replication in the placenta and peripheral organs preceded viral spread to the brain.
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: As there were no substantial differences in the viral titer kinetics and DNA copy numbers between the wild-type MCMV-Smith and MCMV-EGFP even in this study (data not shown), all further experiments were performed using MCMV-EGFP.
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: MCMV-antigen (Ag) + cells in the serial sections prepared from more than 30 MCMV-infected fetal cerebra at each time point were detected using monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) against the MCMV IE1 nuclear protein, the antigen expressed immediately after viral infection, and against the E1 protein, the antigen expressed only during the viral productive phase.
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: As immunohistological staining with both antibodies yielded the same images of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebra, we describe these as "MCMV-Ag + cells" hereafter.
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: MCMV-Ag + cells were found most frequently in the meninges, and then focally in the periventricular area surrounding the lateral ventricles, the third ventricle, and the cerebral aqueduct of the cerebral parenchyma ( Fig. 2C and D).
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: There were no significant differences in the numbers or distribution of the MCMV-Ag + cells in the brains at 3 and at 5 dpi (Fig. 2C).
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: Signals obtained in the in situ hybridization assay for detection of replicated viral DNA corresponded to MCMV-Ag + cells identified in the adjacent section ( Fig. 2D, right panel).
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: Thus, congenital infection in our MCMV model resulted in replicative infection in the fetal cerebrum.
body_text.section: Dynamics of MCMV infection and distribution of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: The type of MCMV-infected cells in the fetal cerebrum was determined by immunohistochemical analysis for MCMV-Ag and various cell markers.
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: In the meninges (Fig. 3A-D), MCMV-Ag + cells were distributed along the CD31 + blood vessels and involved CD31 + endothelial cells in some cases (Fig. 3A, arrow head), while over half of the MCMV-Ag + cells were F4/80 + macrophages (Fig. 3B, arrow head).
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: F4/80+ macrophages existed in the infectious foci twinning around CD31+ endothelial cells (Fig. 3C).
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: In the brain parenchyma ( Fig. 3E-P), MCMV-Ag + cells were detected along the CD31 + blood vessels penetrating into the brain parenchyma from the lateral ventricle (LV) (Fig. 3E).
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: F4/80 + macrophages infiltrated into the infectious foci (Fig. 3F), and existed alongside the CD31 + blood vessels (Fig. 3G).
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: In addition to F4/80 + macrophages, CD31 + endothelial cells (Fig. 3I, arrow head) and NG2 + perivascular cells (pericytes) ( Fig. 3M, arrow head) were occasionally infected with MCMV.
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: Regardless of the number of MCMV-infected cells in the meninges, MCMV-Ag was detected only occasionally in the parenchyma just below the infected meninges.
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: These results indicate that MCMV invasion into the parenchyma occurs via a transvascular process, not as the result of direct invasion from the meninges.
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: In the infectious foci of the cerebral periventricular area (Fig. 3Q-T) and periaqueductal gray matter, most of MCMV-Ag + cells were SOX-2 + NSPCs (Fig. 3Q).
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: Uninfected F4/80 + macrophages crowded around the infectious foci of the NSPCs (Fig. 3R), and infiltrated into the foci (Fig. 3S).
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: The infiltration of uninfected F4/80 + macrophages was found at all infectious foci, and they outnumbered the MCMV-infected macrophages.
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: Thus, in the fetal cerebrum, the major target cells allowing MCMV replication are macrophages and NSPCs.
body_text.section: MCMV invades the fetal brain via the bloodstream and targets macrophages and NSPCs in the cerebrum

body_text.text: As we observed infiltration of uninfected macrophages into the infectious foci, cell numbers and distributions of Iba1 + brain macrophages were compared between the fetal cerebra obtained from mock-and MCMV-infected dams.
body_text.section: MCMV infection induces macrophage infiltration and aberrant distribution of microglia in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: Iba1 + brain macrophages, including microglia, increased in the cerebra at both E16.5 (3 dpi) ( Fig. 4A) and at E18.5 (5 dpi) (Fig. 4B) in the infected fetuses.
body_text.section: MCMV infection induces macrophage infiltration and aberrant distribution of microglia in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: These increases in Iba1 + macrophages were observed predominantly not only around the infectious foci in the meninges and parenchyma ( Fig. 4A arrow headand C), but also in the uninfected area of the MCMV-infected cerebrum.
body_text.section: MCMV infection induces macrophage infiltration and aberrant distribution of microglia in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: At 5 dpi (E18.5), the number of Iba1 + cells in the uninfected area were significantly increased in the meninges, cerebral cortex, and hippocampus in MCMVinfected cerebra compared with the mock-infected cerebra (Fig. 4D).
body_text.section: MCMV infection induces macrophage infiltration and aberrant distribution of microglia in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: Interestingly, in the MCMV-infected cerebra, microglia without viral infection aberrantly appeared in the cortical plate (CP) (Fig. 4B, upper panel), where microglia are usually absent during the fetal period in the mice brain.
body_text.section: MCMV infection induces macrophage infiltration and aberrant distribution of microglia in the fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: 31 Aberrant increase in macrophages/microglia is not due to their in situ proliferation

body_text.text: Therefore, the aberrant increase in macrophages in the MCMV-infected animals is thought not to be due to cell proliferation, but is likely the result of the recruitment of macrophages from other sites.

body_text.text: To investigate the impact of MCMV infection on NSPC proliferation, which reflects their ability to self-renew as a primary aspect of stemness, nuclear BrdU incorporation into SOX2 + NSPCs in the VZ/SVZ was analyzed.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: Infected pregnant mice were pulsed with BrdU at 3 or 5 dpi and the fetal brains were removed 3 h later.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: MCMV-infected NSPCs in the VZ/SVZ did not incorporate BrdU at all (Fig. 7A).
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: Furthermore, BrdU incorporation into NSPCs aside from the infectious foci was also decreased (Fig. 7B  and C).
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: These data indicate that MCMV infection impairs NSPCs proliferation via not only direct viral cytopathicity but also indirect pathways.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: We next examined how the impairment of the stemness of NSPCs in the VZ/SVZ influences cortical development.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: According to the widely accepted model of neocortical development, the upper cortical layers, unique to the mammalian brain, are derived from cortical precursor cells generated in the VZ during the period between E14 and E18.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: 34 We injected BrdU into MCMVinfected pregnant mice at 1 dpi (E14.5) and then collected fetal brains at 5 dpi (E18.5).
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: MCMV infection reduced the number of BrdU-labeled cells arriving at the upper layers of the CP in the E18.5 fetal brains, suggesting MCMV infection disturbs the development of the cortical upper layers (Fig. 7D and E).
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: To exclude the possibility that the reduction in BrdUlabeled cells was due to circulatory disturbance, we analyzed expression of the T-box brain 1 (Tbr1) transcription factor protein in the cerebral cortex, which is involved in the migration and differentiation of neurons, specifically within layer VI of developing six-layered cortex.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: 35 There were no significant differences in the number of Tbr1 + neurons destined for layer VI between the mock-and MCMV-infected cerebra at 5 dpi ( Fig. 8A and B), suggesting that MCMV infection after E13.5 produces little effect of the development of the lower layers.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: In contrast, the number of Brn2 + neuronal cells in the cerebral cortex, especially in the upper CP, was reduced in the MCMVinfected brain (Fig. 8A and B).
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: Brn2, POU-homeodomain transcription factor (Pou3f2), is required for the production of the neural cells in layers II/III, as they migrate to the proper position from their departure point in the VZ.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: 36,37 These data indicate that MCMV infection impairs the onset of Brn2 expression in NSPCs, resulting in a reduction in the number of neurons destined for the upper cortical layers.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: Collectively, MCMV infection impairs the stemness of NSPCs via broad and indirect mechanisms, resulting in disordered cerebral corticogenesis.
body_text.section: Effects of MCMV infection on the stemness of NSPCs and cerebral corticogenesis

body_text.text: To elucidate the mechanism involved in the reactions of brain macrophages and aberrant localization of microglia, we evaluated the immune activation status of MCMVinfected fetal cerebra.
body_text.section: Immune activation in MCMV-infected fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: For this purpose, expression levels of iNOS, MCP-1/CCL2, and representative inflammatory cytokines in the whole cerebra including the meninges were analyzed (Fig. 9).
body_text.section: Immune activation in MCMV-infected fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: Expressions of iNOS, TNF-a, and IL-1b, reflecting macrophage activation, increased markedly in the MCMV-infected cerebra with time after infection, but not in the mock-infected cerebra.
body_text.section: Immune activation in MCMV-infected fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: IL-10 also showed similar mRNA expression kinetics.
body_text.section: Immune activation in MCMV-infected fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: Interestingly, INF-a and -b, as type I interferons, contributed little to innate immunity in the MCMV-infected fetal cerebra, although they usually play an important role in the earliest innate host defense against viral infections.
body_text.section: Immune activation in MCMV-infected fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: INF-c and IL-6 showed a delayed increase, and MCP-1 expression peaked at 3 dpi in the MCMV-infected cerebra.
body_text.section: Immune activation in MCMV-infected fetal cerebrum

body_text.text: To determine the cellular populations responsible for the increased expression of iNOS and cytokines in the MCMV-infected fetal cerebra, four cell populations, monocyte/macrophages, microglia, CD11b À leukocytes, and other cerebral cells, were prepared by cell sorting during flow cytometry, and the expression of iNOS and cytokines in each population was analyzed (Fig. 10).
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: The monocyte/macrophage population in the MCMV-infected cerebra was exclusively responsible for the expression of the proinflammatory cytokines, TNF-a, IL-1b, and IL-6.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: Expression of iNOS and INF-b were also prominent in the monocyte/macrophage population, and substantially observed in the other populations.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: In addition, the monocyte/macrophage population contributed to the expression of IL-10.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: These data appear to well explain the activated immune status of the monocyte/macrophage population in the infectious foci.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: In contrast, the microglia contributed little to the mRNA expression of pro-and antiinflammatory cytokines, except for iNOS, INF-a, and -b.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: The expression of iNOS in the microglia of the MCMVinfected cerebra was reduced compared with that of the mock-infected cerebra.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: Except for the aberrant but minor expression of INF-a and -b, these results indicated a silent or suppressive immune status of microglia in the MCMV-infected fetal cerebrum.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: The CD11b À leukocyte population was primarily responsible for the expression of INF-c.
body_text.section: Differential expression of iNOS, inflammatory cytokines, and interferons between activated macrophages and microglia

body_text.text: Although this population had been supposed to consist of CD3 + /CD11b À T cells and B220 + /CD11b À B cells, we found B cells were almost absent (Fig. 5C).

body_text.text: Therefore, INF-c, probably derived from T cells, contrib-uted to the expression of iNOS during the late phase of MCMV infection.

body_text.text: The present study, using the mouse model of intraplacental MCMV infection, focused on the effects of MCMV infection on late corticogenesis from E14.5 to E18.5.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: This time frame corresponds to the period from 11 to 15 weeks during the first to second trimesters of human pregnancy.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 8 During this period, the upper cortical layers II and III are generated both in mice and humans, and disturbances in these layers in humans have been implicated in the etiologies of neurodevelopmental disorders, such as schizophrenia.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 38 The neonatal mice models with intracranial, 30,39 or intraperitoneal MCMV inoculation 40 instead of MCMV intraplacental infection, have offered important of the neuropathogenesis of congenital CMV infection.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: However, in these models, it was difficult to investigate the effects of MCMV infection on cerebral corticogenesis in terms of the route of infection and the stage of CNS development.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In this study, we have established an improved model system of congenital MCMV infection using a highly accurate and less invasive method for intraplacental MCMV inoculation based on the use of a fine glass micropipette.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: This less invasive method improved the survival rate of fetuses infected with MCMV intraplacentally.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Furthermore, it minimized the influence of immune response incidentally induced by surgical procedures.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The main findings of the present study are as follows: (1) intraplacentally inoculated MCMV invades the cerebrum via the bloodstream from the placenta in the same way as congenital HCMV infection; (2) brain macrophages are not only the major cells infected in the MCMVinfected fetal brain, but also crucial cells for primitive innate immune response; (3) MCMV directly infects NSPCs and impairs their stemness.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Furthermore, we found that MCMV infection impairs their stemness by global and indirect mechanisms during the late cerebral corticogenesis.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: As the global and indirect mechanisms for the impairment of the stemness of NSPCs in MCMV-infected fetal brain, we would like to propose the disturbances caused by soluble mediators from activated macrophages and the alteration of the brain microenvironment due to In our mouse model, multifocal and disseminated MCMV infectious foci were formed through the whole fetal body, including the brain, as shown in congenital HCMV infection.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 41 In the cerebrum of our mouse model, MCMV infectious foci were distributed along blood vessels throughout the brain parenchyma and meninges, with the periventricular area as a preferred site of MCMV infection.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The infectious foci mostly consisted of infiltrated macrophages, and only a part of them were infected with MCMV.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Since immature myelomonocytic leukocytes have been shown to participate in MCMV dissemination via the bloodstream, 42 it is supposed that these immature monocyte/macrophage lineage cells may contribute to transvascular invasion of blood-borne MCMV into the fetal cerebrum.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In the present study, it is worthy of note that focal MCMV infection of the fetal cerebrum globally induced a dramatic and aberrant increase in brain macrophages, including microglia, and this increase was dependent on the recruitment of precursor cells from other sites rather than in situ proliferation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Activated macrophages were few in number compared with the other brain macrophage populations, but exclusively expressed MHC class II and iNOS, indicating macrophage activation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These activated macrophages in the infectious foci were the primary source of iNOS and proinflammatory cytokines, TNF-a and IL-1b, which have been reported to suppress MCMV replication.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 43,44 Considering the delayed expression of INF-c, we speculate that the expression of these mediators may be first induced by the direct interaction between MCMV and macrophages, perhaps via mechanisms involving the activation of pattern recognition receptors.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 45 This macrophage activation was restricted to the infectious foci with active MCMV replication, as reported previously for the MCMV infection of the postnatal brain, 30 and possibly prevented the spread of MCMV infection.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It is likely that both the activated macrophages in the infectious foci and the recruited meningeal macrophages derive from the fetal liver where the major fetal hematopoiesis occurs after E12, instead of from the yolk sac in mice.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 46 In contrast to the activated macrophages, microglia showed no potent activation but improperly appeared in the CP associated with an aberrant increase in their number, suggesting this improper and excessive distribution of microglia could adversely affect cerebral development.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: However, the source of the increase in microglia, whether primitive macrophages in the yolk sac or fetal liver monocytes, remains to be clarified.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 47 With regard to the neuropathogenesis of congenital CMV infection, great attention has been paid to NSPCs, 19,20 as HCMV preferentially infects the VZ/SVZ in the brains of congenitally infected patients.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 48 A loss of stemness in NSPCs caused by direct CMV cytopathicity has been demonstrated in previous in vitro studies.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: [11][12][13] Our intraplacental MCMV infection model simulated transplacental HCHV infection, and demonstrated that intraplacentally inoculated MCMV preferentially infects NSPCs in the developing fetal cerebrum and directly impairs their stemness.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: At the same time, global and indirect impairment of NSPCs was observed in the MCMVinfected fetal cerebra.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Postnatal mouse models infected by intraventricular MCMV injection showed delayed cerebellar development with decreases in granular neuron proliferation and migration 40 and improved development of MCMV-infected cerebellum in response to suppression of inflammation by glucocorticoid treatment.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 49 These reports are highly suggestive of an impact by focal MCMV infection on CNS development via broad inflammatory responses.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The dysregulation of immune mediators has been suggested to adversely affect neurodevelopment.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 50 In this study, the induction of iNOS, TNF-a, IL-1b, and IL-10 from activated macrophages infiltrating infections foci was the earliest primitive innate immune response against MCMV infection in the fetal cerebrum.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These immune mediators, TNF-a, IL-1b, and IL-10, are known to adversely influence the stemness of NSPCs and are associated with neurodevelopmental disorders, such as schizophrenia and epilepsy.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: [51][52][53][54][55] In addition to the activated macrophage response, MCMV infection in the developing fetal cerebrum induced improper and excess distribution of microglia, which physiologically regulate NSPCs and supports cerebral cortical development.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 56,57 iNOS expression was suppressed in these aberrantly recruited microglia during MCMV infection.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: NO produced by iNOS is an important player in neuronal development.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: 58 These aberrantly recruited microglia may disturb normal brain development via alterations in the microenvironment not only due to their improper and excessive distribution in the fetal brain, but also due to their adverse immune response.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Recent studies have proposed an association between aberrant microglial status and impairment of corticogenesis in neurodevelopmental diseases, such as schizophrenia.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our present study implies that inflammatory responses during embryogenesis can trigger microglial dysregulation and that such dysregulation may result in certain kinds of neuropsychiatric diseases.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It would be interesting to see the relationship between neurophysiological and neuroethological outcomes and aberrant microglia status in the brains of adult mice that survive congenital MCMV infection in our model.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In conclusion, we have established an improved mouse model that can closely reflect congenital CMV infection in humans.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The model indicated that immune responses to viral infection, including aberrant recruitment and activation of brain macrophages, compromise the stemness of NSPCs, thus resulting in neurodevelopmental disorders.
